They only started requiring and offering a course on mathematical proofs when they wanted to hop on the actuarial science bandwagon. My exposure to more abstract math has helped me understand the finer points of using math in physics and engineering work. However, I still struggle with rigorous mathematical treatments. So,  I really have a love-hate relationship with math.    I really should have taken a history of mathematics course in my department.  There is a slight disjoint between how things in math and science are developed and are taught.  I think Special Relativity is an excellent example.  Everyone gets hung up on the speed of light because many books talk about the Michelson-Morely experiment.  Einstein was aware of their results, but he was more inspired by Faraday's Laws of Induction.  Basically, Einstein assumed Maxwell's Theory of Electromagnetism was more fundamental than Newton's Mechanics, then determined how that affected relativity. Despite having a B.S. in Physics, I did not know that until I did my own research into the topic.

Given y=2*x, when we take the derivative dy/dx, this doesn't imply that y necessarily equals 2.   Only if we plot the derivative as a second equation on the same graph, then we would say that y=2 for the second equation.  But it is an unrelated y from the first equation.  What you are finding is the slope of the tangent line.  It is a trivial case for a linear equation, because the tangent line is the original equation, so it isn't an interesting example.  Continuing on with your second example, of y=x^2, consider the point when x=3.   We calculate the equation of a line in the form of y=m*x+b, that will intersect our original equation (y=x^2) at the point x=3.   We take the derivative to determine the value of m, and get m=6.  We then set y=9 (the original value of x^2 at x=3), and x=3, and solve for b.  We get b= -9.   We now can construct the equation of the tangent line which is y = 6*x - 9.  Graph the equations on the same plot, and study what happens near the point where x=3 and y=9: y = x^2 y = 6*x - 9  Observe how the tangent line intersects at this point, but doesn't intersect at a second point in the immediate vicinity.  The tangent line has a slope that locally matches the slope of the curved graph.   That is what the derivative is.  We are calcualting the value of m, in y=m*x+b, such that the line locally resembles the original curve at the point of tangency.  It touches at one point, and no other point immediately nearby, and it resembles the local slope of the original curve.

If you actually make it through this calculus series, you'll have answers to all these questions.

dx means infinitesimal change in x.  Higher order derivatives mean rate of change in a previous order of derivative.  For instance, acceleration is the derivative of velocity, which itself is the derivative of position.  To add onto this, jerk is the derivative of acceleration, which is necessary to study when designing roads and roller coasters, to mitigate sudden changes in g-force to the riders.  Yes, it does mean finding a slope of a slope to some extent.  It is approximately a way to measure how concave or curved a function's graph is at a given point.  "Why would you want or need to find an area 3 times?"  An application of triple integrals is summing up the mass of a region of space that is not uniform.  Perhaps you have an object that is made of some kind of resin filled with iron powder, whose density is not uniform, and you'd like to calculate the total density.  Possibly you also want to determine dynamics properties like moment of inertia and center of mass.  Your CAD programs do triple integrals to determine mass, moment of inertia, and center of mass, which you would be interested in knowing for a manufactured part that is part of a machine.  "And where's the proof that these "rules" actually work?? I've never seen any of that in any lesson. Teachers sure as hell don't explain it. "  Probably because knowing how to do the proof is either beyond the scope of the course, or not the main purpose of teaching it to you.   The proofs are well-documented and easy to look-up if you care to learn.  You can look up "proof of the power rule for any real exponent", or "proof of the product rule" and find a limit proof of it.  This is the kind of work that is best left to you to read in the textbook, while teaching you how to apply the rules is the main focus of the class.  "Did whoever invented this crap say to the other, eh, yeah that looks good, we'll call that right. " No, there are formal proofs of everything mathematicians contribute to our body of knowledge.  They had a burden of proof to convince their contemporary peers that their ideas work.  "And now we're supposed to believe shuffling around parentheses and letters and getting an "answer" of parentheses and letters is somehow a useful skill?" Because it enables you to generalize a mathematical problem that may apply to the real world, so that you have a closed-form solution that could apply to any specifications you give it.  A reason why this is so important: when programmers develop software that will do hundreds if not thousands of calculations for every input you give it, they need to know a generalized solution to problems, so it isn't using computationally intensive "solver" methods every time.  It's much more efficient to compute a quadratic formula for instance, than it is use trial and error to narrow down the solutions by guessing what they are and refining them.   An application where this is used, is 3-D rendering, where light hits a body at two points, and you need to calculate where those two points are.

That way the movements can look realistic and match a player's instincts from the real world.  It also is used in designing machinery, buildings, roads, bridges, electric circuits, and all sorts of innovations we've had since the industrial revolution...and even before then.  The examples you see in a textbook may seem like too simplistic of a case to have value in the real world, and be nowhere near what people who use Calculus professionally might do.  But the reason you get such examples is to come up with an application of the concepts you can easily relate to, minimize the complexity of multiple concepts coexisting in the same problem, and use as a building block to understand how to put together dozens of concepts from all over science, to eventually learn to solve problems professionally.

Your smartphone has microscopic mass on spring systems inside it, called accelerometers, that measure acceleration.  It measures the equilibrium position of these microscopic springs, and gives you a read-out of how much force per unit mass it takes to accelerate your phone.   It is ultimately measuring your phone's acceleration.  You can download a physics app that gives you a read-out of the accelerometers in the phone.  In part, the accelerometer also measures gravitational field, and cannot tell the difference between gravitational field and acceleration in the opposite direction.  But when you calibrate it at rest on our planet's surface, you tell it what gravity to expect for zero acceleration.  It then gives all other measurements of apparent gravitational field, as a readout of acceleration.

Mathematics in general is the KISS principle in reverse.  The idea is to start with a simple concept, and expand it to see just how far we can take it, and the entirety of what we can learn from it.   Mathematics is the study of patterns, and finding the entire scope of where the pattern can still apply.

The reason why something so basic (area under a curve and slope of a tangent line) evolve into something so complicated, is because the array of functions we can use are so complicated.  That's why you learn how to apply calculus to function products, function sums, function quotients, and function compositions, as well as exponentials, logarithms, trigonometry, and inverse trigonometry.  There's a lot more you could add to that list of functions, many that you may have never even heard of (coshes and sinches, Bessel functions, error functions, Ackerman function, Lambert W function, and countless others).  There are applications of the derivative or integral of all of these.

According to the information we have today about what the Greeks before Christ determined, the Greeks came up with the foundation for the concept of Calculus, but didn't complete it to the degree that Newton and Leibnitz had.  Whether they had completed it or not, was information we had lost over the years.   We don't know what was in that original text, so it is all speculation as to whether the ancient Greeks did complete Calculus to the degree we know it today.  I would think that they very likely could've completed the body of knowledge that we call Calculus today, and I find it hard to believe that they would come up with Zeno's paradox, and then never finish its implications to the point of practical application.  They certainly knew how to produce n-gons to calculate pi, so Riemann sums seem like a logical extension of this knowledge.

There are plenty of problems that even Wolfram Alpha cannot solve that professional mathematicians are working on today.   There are also solutions beyond the scope of a class you might be in, that Wolfram Alpha will give you as a solution.  For instance, cos(acos(2)), your trig teacher might tell you has no solution, because acos(2) has no real solution, but Wolfram Alpha will give you a solution, and confirm that 2 is one possible answer.   Wolfram Alpha can appeal to complex numbers as an intermediate step, when part of your equation has no real solution.  Inventing new kinds of math is a process that has been happening for thousands of years, as we develop a bigger and bigger picture of what a number even is, and what we can do with it.   Whether math is invented or discovered is a deep philosophical question.  Some see it as a concept that always exists, and people just need to discover it and find a language to describe it.   Others see it as mathematicians invent the solution to solve the problem, just like an engineer inventing a new product.  It is a combination of the two, and I see "coined" can be a more neutral term to describe how new mathematical concepts become part of our toolbox.

I got straight A's in calculus in college,  It was kinda like learning the rules of chess and using them in sequence to get a process of elimination to win.  I did homework of 30 complex problems in the half hour before class while classmates were struggling with the last problems in the book (usually the hardest).  It was so easy I had time to draw caricatures and pictures between the problems, much to my profs amusement.  (I was premed and artist).  But I never really understood what the point of calculus.  I wound up thinking, Who cares what's under a curve?  Curves were trends - up, down, flat - predicting results.  I just couldn't see why you'd want to calculate the 'result' for every possibility.  I mean if you want to know how hot it was in Arizona on such and such date ... heck.... just follow the line up to the function and get it.  No rectangles needed for an infinitely thin line.   How useful was EVERY temperature of EVERY day at the same time going to be?  This thinking led to struggling when my calculus met physics.  Physics was also easy for me .... except when it met calculus .... because again, I saw no point to ruining physics to get a curve nobody cared about since what we wanted was real values.   Where was the cannonball at t=10, known weight, angle and force?  Who cared about the rest of the trip?  And why did we need area under a curve when the axes had most of the relevant information and the function line had the trend?  These are the questions students ask but can't put words to them.  In fact when a student asked, "What is the point of this?" the beginning calculus instructor went ballistic about how if they didn't want to be in college, why were they wasting chair space?  He missed the point of the question entirely!  None of us dared pursue that line of inquiry, whether we understood or not.  This is  the guy grading our papers!  When it comes to problem credit points or asking him in office hours,  it doesn't pay to make him mad.    This video filled in some of the gaps my instructors took for granted.   Thanks. :)

right, but this is also the difference the video is talking about: that there are conceptually infinite processes we can apply and never actually reach the thing in question, but - at some point - we arrive at something which is functionally useful and meaningful.  the fact of saying "i touch the wall when i run into it" and differentiating between "well, technically, there is actually still space between my atoms and the wall's atoms, so no actual contact was made.." and "okay but i now have a headache, so i hit something".    i think calculus touches on something that mathematics - in general - does well with "significant figures" and that philosophy often gets tangled up in: levels of abstraction.  relevance.  infinite levels of "well, actually" doesn't give us something to work with, but accepting that there is a margin of error/level of abstraction involved allows us to understand when we can stop and begin applying what we're approximating.  when we need to ask the question of "where is the point of what constitutes the wall, the place where i will feel an impact?", this ability to ask questions on these two levels is important: one leads to conceptual fidelity and the other leads to .. not banging our heads into walls.

Sophistocated example: the limit as n goes to infinity of 1/n is 0. @TomSarracino  Using Riemann sums to compute every integral is a lot more computationally intensive, than solving the problem by hand first analytically, and then implementing the solution in a computer program.  When you need to solve the same integral hundreds, if not thousands of times within a computer program, it helps to have the programmer implement the analytic solution first, rather than using Riemann sums for everything.  Even if you only need the accuracy of a Riemann sum, there still is value in having a closed-form analytic solution.  The closed-form analytic solution also allows us to explore what would happen if we vary the parameters of the problem and understand it in generalized sense, while a Riemann sum is a dead-end to only one solution of one integral.

@jamescollins4500  Kepler determined his laws from measured data, measured by Tycho Brahe.  He didn't know why the results of planetary orbits were what they were, he just came up with observational laws to mathematically describe the orbits.  Kinematics, rather than dynamics.  He foresaw that a force of somekind, likely originating from the sun, must be making it all happen.  As a contemporary of Galileo, he was a proponent of heliocentrism.   Galileo provided observational proof of heliocentrism, suggested by a student of his, that Venus would go through a full set of phases.  Galileo also laid the groundwork for Newton, such as confirming mass independence of free fall, determining that an object's default state of motion is a constant velocity, and coming up with the concept of relative motion analysis and reference frames.  Newton picked up, where Galileo and Kepler left off.  He determined the complete foundation for mechanics in general, and the branch of mathematics of Calculus to put it all together.  His goal was to provide a holistic explanation of Kepler's laws, from first principles, which motivated him to discover Calculus.  Leibnitz was a contemporary of Newton's, who independently also discovered Calculus.  The English and Germans disagree on who really was the founder of Calculus, but the truth is, they determined it independently, and both had valuable contributions we continue to use today.

But...can you do better?   Can you make a calculation of area more accurate, given a list of points along a curve, and no actual equation of a curve?  Or, given a function that is not possible to integrate analytically in closed--form, but such that you can evaluate points on the function, and use those points to calculate the integral?  The answer is yes.  First we can approximate it with midpoint rectangles.   Next, we can approximate trapezoids between given points.  And even more advanced, is Simpson's rule, that implements parabolas to account for curvature between points.   Simpson's rule is even written in a way that even though it is derived from parabolas, you don't need to even think about parabolas when evaluating a numeric integration with it.

Students are taught the concept of slope in the first few weeks of Algebra I with y = mx + b ; essentially they are taught how to calculate the derivative of a linear equation from day one, so they get the concept of slope. I would guess that Leibnitz's notation became the most popular, out of typographical necessity when the technology of typing was the most primitive.  The same reason a lot of letters from old English got scrapped in favor of digraphs, like the letter thorn that is now represented with a th.  Leibnitz's notation just needs letters and the slash, while Newton's notation needs the ability to overlay dots above letters.   Leibnitz's notation also has the advantage of capturing the meaning of the derivative and integral within it.  Newton's notation has the advantage of being space-efficient, and time-efficient to handwrite, which is why it is making a renaissance in modern times, and even being preferred for engineering and physics.  Now that typing technology has improved, and we can overlay all kinds of marks on letters with modern computers.

Not exactly sure what that’s supposed to mean but I think a good solid, simple definition of calculus is “the study of rates of change.” Whether you’re differentiating, integrating, testing for convergence, finding tangent planes and so on you’re always concerned about how a function (or sequence) value changes as the inputs (usually in a neighborhood around an input) change. There’s a lot of fancy terms but it all just boils down to answering the question: if I change the input how much does it change the output?

mark hughes That’s an interesting way to try to learn. So basically no calculus is not an extension of arithmetic like algebra is. A lot of calculus can be done with real inputs and outputs and only algebraic functions, but you can have multivariate inputs (each of which has a number as an output) and vector input and output functions. When you’re doing the work in calculus a lot of time you deal with transcendental functions which don’t have polynomial solutions (examples are trig and exponential functions). So no it’s not a further abstraction of arithmetic like high school algebra tends to be. That’s not to say it’s ridiculously hard, I think it’s just hard for a lot of people to grasp concepts that deal with infinity in a real way for the first time in their learning career. Calculus isn’t really as scary as it’s made out to be. When I took the calculus sequence I thought it was more fun that algebra, trig, or geometry were.

A (e.g. Rig-Veda 1.105.17) formula to find the area of a circle is mentioned showing that the Rishis knew of pi, approximating it to be equal to 22/7. The word Bijaganitam means “the other mathematics” and was given to math like, for example, what we call algebraic forms of computation. Eventually another notation that people called “Indian numerals” evolved from the Brahmi numerals and assumed common use. But under the dictatorship of Mohammad in the 7th/8th centuries, Arabs invaded and conquered the land from India, across northern Africa, to Spain & the math eventually spread in the world.
